elements.content: Two isostructural the -type DyIII coordination networks were successfully constructed based on a pair of analogous tribenzoate bridging ligands with phenyl and triazinyl central spacers. Notably, the active triazinyl group can obviously enhance the capability and selectivity of CO2 sorption for the porous framework.
elements.clean_text: Two isostructural  the -type DyIII coordination networks were successfully constructed based on a pair of analogous tribenzoate bridging ligands with phenyl and triazinyl central spacers. Notably, the active triazinyl group can obviously enhance the capability and selectivity of CO2 sorption for the porous framework.

elements.content: Replacing the phenyl spacer of benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoate by triazinyl can lead to a significant improvement in the capability and selectivity for CO2 sorption in the resulting isostructural DyIII−carboxylate porous framework.
elements.clean_text: Replacing the phenyl spacer of benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoate by triazinyl can lead to a significant improvement in the capability and selectivity for CO2 sorption in the resulting isostructural DyIII-carboxylate porous framework.

elements.content: The crystalline porous materials, namely metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), have attracted widespread interest for their fascinating structures and potential applications in many realms. In particular, the sorption performance is primary to MOF materials for their highly porous inherence, and in this context, the study on fuel storage, CO2 capture, hydrocarbon separation, et cetera has made great progress. As we all know, the properties of crystalline materials essentially rely on their intrinsic compositions and structures. Thus, the active domains within the host frameworks of MOF materials (e.g., open metal sites and exposed heteroatoms) will be critical to their gas sorption behaviors. Normally, the open metal sites are generated by the removal of coordination solvents, and the exposed heteroatoms can be achieved by introducing the functional substituents on ligands. However, in most cases, the exclusion of solvent ligands around metal centers will lead to the collapse of porous frameworks. Also, the sorption properties can be modified by adding the active groups on ligands, while the shrinkage of available space is inevitable under such circumstances, which in some respects is conflicting for the higher adsorbing capacity.
elements.clean_text: The crystalline porous materials, namely metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), have attracted widespread interest for their fascinating structures and potential applications in many realms. In particular, the sorption performance is primary to MOF materials for their highly porous inherence, and in this context, the study on fuel storage, CO2 capture, hydrocarbon separation, et cetera has made great progress. As we all know, the properties of crystalline materials essentially rely on their intrinsic compositions and structures. Thus, the active domains within the host frameworks of MOF materials (e.g., open metal sites and exposed heteroatoms) will be critical to their gas sorption behaviors. Normally, the open metal sites are generated by the removal of coordination solvents, and the exposed heteroatoms can be achieved by introducing the functional substituents on ligands. However, in most cases, the exclusion of solvent ligands around metal centers will lead to the collapse of porous frameworks. Also, the sorption properties can be modified by adding the active groups on ligands, while the shrinkage of available space is inevitable under such circumstances, which in some respects is conflicting for the higher adsorbing capacity.

elements.content: In this connection, the modification of ligand backbones by heteroatom replacement can be a promising approach to improve the sorption properties of MOFs, where the inert phenyl or cyclopentadienyl groups are replaced with heterocycles as the active region. Significantly, the sorption investigation on such isostructural MOFs with almost identical voids but different active sites can offer a nice platform for profound understanding of the interactions between host frameworks and gas molecules, and the sorption mechanisms thereof. Unfortunately, just a tiny variation of ligands will lead to the formation of distinct crystalline products for MOFs, and as a result, only two sets of isostructural CuII-based MOFs have been constructed with this strategy thus far. Herein, we present two isostructural DyIII MOFs based on two similar trigonal building blocks, benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoate (BTB) and 4,4′,4″-s-triazine-2,4,6-triyltribenzoate (TATB), which are differentiating only in the central phenyl and triazinyl spacers, respectively (see ). Remarkably, 477-MOF featuring an active triazinyl moiety shows superior capacity for CO2 capture and adsorption selectivity over other gases, in comparison to the phenyl-based 476-MOF.
elements.clean_text: In this connection, the modification of ligand backbones by heteroatom replacement can be a promising approach to improve the sorption properties of MOFs, where the inert phenyl or cyclopentadienyl groups are replaced with heterocycles as the active region. Significantly, the sorption investigation on such isostructural MOFs with almost identical voids but different active sites can offer a nice platform for profound understanding of the interactions between host frameworks and gas molecules, and the sorption mechanisms thereof. Unfortunately, just a tiny variation of ligands will lead to the formation of distinct crystalline products for MOFs, and as a result, only two sets of isostructural CuII-based MOFs have been constructed with this strategy thus far. Herein, we present two isostructural DyIII MOFs based on two similar trigonal building blocks, benzene-1,3,5-tribenzoate (BTB) and 4,4',4"-s-triazine-2,4,6-triyltribenzoate (TATB), which are differentiating only in the central phenyl and triazinyl spacers, respectively (see ). Remarkably, 477-MOF featuring an active triazinyl moiety shows superior capacity for CO2 capture and adsorption selectivity over other gases, in comparison to the phenyl-based 476-MOF.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Illustration of the [Dy<sub>2</sub>(HCOO)] SBU and the Interacting 8-fold Tecton (indicated by different
colors) via BTB or TATB Ligands</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" position="float" xlink:href="ic-2016-00760x_0004.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
elements.clean_text: 1  Illustration of the [Dy2(HCOO)] SBU and the Interacting 8-fold Tecton (indicated by different colors) via BTB or TATB Ligands

elements.content: Colorless cubic crystals for {[Dy2L8/3(HCOO)]­(Me2NH2)3(DMF)7(CH3OH)7(H2O)7} n (L = BTB for 476-MOF and TATB for 477-MOF) were similarly synthesized by solvothermal reactions of Dy­(NO3)3 with the trigonal tectons in DMF-CH3OH solvent (see for details). Single crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that 476-MOF and 477-MOF are isostructural, crystallizing in the cubic Im3̅ space group (see ). The dimeric [Dy2(HCOO)] secondary building unit (SBU) is afforded (see ), in which the HCOO– bridge is disordered to adapt the high T h symmetry. Such a structural pattern is unprecedented according to a latest search of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD). Each DyIII ion takes the 9-coordinated monocapped square prism geometry (), completed by eight oxygen atoms from four chelating carboxylates and one oxygen atom from the bridging formate ion. All carboxylates of the organic ligands take the chelating mode with DyIII center to extend the [Dy2(HCOO)] SBUs into a 3D porous framework (see ). Furthermore, two such networks are entangled into each other to form a 2-fold interpenetrating architecture (see ). In each network, two types of cage-like voids are observed, where the mesoporous cage with a diameter of 2.3 nm is constituted by eight trigonal ligands and 12 DyIII centers (a), while the microporous cage of 1.6 nm in diameter is constructed from eight ligands and six [Dy2(HCOO)] SBUs (b). Further, each microporous cage is embedded into a mesoporous section from the other set of independent network, which will reduce the voids of the overall 3D framework (c and ). Strong aromatic interactions exist between the parallel central aromatic rings coming from two distinct networks, with the centroid-to-centroid distances of ca. 3.37 Å (476-MOF) and 3.41 Å (477-MOF), which will also contribute to the stability of interpenetrating patterns (). The PLATON analysis reveals that the effective free volume is 63.1%/62.6% per unit cell in 476-MOF/477-MOF, without considering the Me2NH2 + cations and solvent guests. Topologically, each ligand takes the 3-connected fashion to interact with three DyIII centers, while each DyIII can be viewed as a 5-connected node surrounded by four ligands and one formate anion. Therefore, the structure for 476-MOF or 477-MOF can be properly ascribed to a 2-fold interpenetrating binodal (3,5)-connected network with a point symbol of (48.64.812.104) (). Alternatively, when [Dy2(HCOO)] is simplified as the node, linked by eight surrounding trigonal ligands, such 3D structures can be reduced to the binodal (3,8)-connected the -type networks with 2-fold interpenetration (see d). Similar reticular topology is also observed in TATB-based PCN-9 and PCN-17 MOFs, in which the two entangled networks are combined by bridging sulfate anions.

Single crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that 476-MOF and 477-MOF are isostructural, crystallizing in the cubic Im3̅ space group (see ). The dimeric [Dy2(HCOO)] secondary building unit (SBU) is afforded (see ), in which the HCOO- bridge is disordered to adapt the high T  h  symmetry. Such a structural pattern is unprecedented according to a latest search of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD). Each DyIII ion takes the 9-coordinated monocapped square prism geometry (), completed by eight oxygen atoms from four chelating carboxylates and one oxygen atom from the bridging formate ion. All carboxylates of the organic ligands take the chelating mode with DyIII center to extend the [Dy2(HCOO)] SBUs into a 3D porous framework (see ). Further, each microporous cage is embedded into a mesoporous section from the other set of independent network, which will reduce the voids of the overall 3D framework (c and ). Strong aromatic interactions exist between the parallel central aromatic rings coming from two distinct networks, with the centroid-to-centroid distances of ca. 3.37 Å (476-MOF) and 3.41 Å (477-MOF), which will also contribute to the stability of interpenetrating patterns (). The PLATON analysis reveals that the effective free volume is 63.1%/62.6% per unit cell in 476-MOF/477-MOF, without considering the Me2NH2 + cations and solvent guests. Topologically, each ligand takes the 3-connected fashion to interact with three DyIII centers, while each DyIII can be viewed as a 5-connected node surrounded by four ligands and one formate anion. Alternatively, when [Dy2(HCOO)] is simplified as the node, linked by eight surrounding trigonal ligands, such 3D structures can be reduced to the binodal (3,8)-connected  the -type networks with 2-fold interpenetration (see d). Similar reticular topology is also observed in TATB-based PCN-9 and PCN-17 MOFs, in which the two entangled networks are combined by bridging sulfate anions.

elements.content: Crystal structures of 476-MOF/477-MOF. (a) Mesoporous and (b) nanoporous cage. (c) 2-fold interpenetrating motif formed by the inset of a nanoscale cage into a mesoscale cage. (d) Augmented version of the 2-fold interpenetrating the -type framework.
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structures of 476-MOF/477-MOF. (a) Mesoporous and (b) nanoporous cage. (c) 2-fold interpenetrating motif formed by the inset of a nanoscale cage into a mesoscale cage. (d) Augmented version of the 2-fold interpenetrating  the -type framework.

elements.content: The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves of 476-MOF and 477-MOF () indicate that the first weight loss from 20 to 270 °C corresponds to a loss of solvent guests. The subsequent weight loss occurs in the 330–390 °C range, which can be ascribed to the exclusion of dimethylammonium cations. Beyond that temperature, pyrolysis of the host framework is observed. To evaluate the porosity for 476-MOF and 477-MOF, gas adsorption experiments were carried out by using the activated materials at different temperatures (see for details). 476-MOF and 477-MOF display similar type I isotherms (see ) with saturated uptakes of 266 and 274 cm3 g–1 for N2 at 77 K and 1 atm. Fitting the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation to N2 adsorption isotherms gives the estimated surface areas of 898 and 902 m2 g–1 for 476-MOF and 477-MOF, respectively, which are higher than those for the reported TATB-based PCN-17 series (606–820 m2 g–1). The H2 adsorption isotherm for 476-MOF indicates a moderate uptake of 1.60 wt % (179 cm3 g–1) at 77 K and 1 atm, while 477-MOF shows a slightly higher uptake of 1.77 wt % (198 cm3 g–1) under the same conditions. Also, the maximum O2 uptake is 302 cm3 g–1 (43.1 wt %) for 476-MOF, and a higher uptake of 330 cm3 g–1 (47.1 wt %) is for 477-MOF.
elements.clean_text: The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves of 476-MOF and 477-MOF () indicate that the first weight loss from 20 to 270 °C corresponds to a loss of solvent guests. The subsequent weight loss occurs in the 330-390 °C range, which can be ascribed to the exclusion of dimethylammonium cations. Beyond that temperature, pyrolysis of the host framework is observed. To evaluate the porosity for 476-MOF and 477-MOF, gas adsorption experiments were carried out by using the activated materials at different temperatures (see  for details). 476-MOF and 477-MOF display similar type I isotherms (see ) with saturated uptakes of 266 and 274 cm3 g-1 for N2 at 77 K and 1 atm. Fitting the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation to N2 adsorption isotherms gives the estimated surface areas of 898 and 902 m2 g-1 for 476-MOF and 477-MOF, respectively, which are higher than those for the reported TATB-based PCN-17 series (606-820 m2 g-1). The H2 adsorption isotherm for 476-MOF indicates a moderate uptake of 1.60 wt % (179 cm3 g-1) at 77 K and 1 atm, while 477-MOF shows a slightly higher uptake of 1.77 wt % (198 cm3 g-1) under the same conditions. Also, the maximum O2 uptake is 302 cm3 g-1 (43.1 wt %) for 476-MOF, and a higher uptake of 330 cm3 g-1 (47.1 wt %) is for 477-MOF.

elements.content: Gas adsorption isotherms for 476-MOF and 477-MOF at 77 and 273 K (closed/open shapes: adsorption/desorption).
elements.clean_text: 2  Gas adsorption isotherms for 476-MOF and 477-MOF at 77 and 273 K (closed/open shapes: adsorption/desorption).

elements.content: The gas sorption isotherms for 476-MOF and 477-MOF at 273 and 293 K ( and ) indicate their extremely poor capture capacities for N2, O2, and H2 (<3.7 cm3 g–1 at both temperatures) in contrast with those for CO2 and CH4 gases. Both MOFs have comparable CH4 uptakes, 12.2/14.7 cm3 g–1 at 273 K and 10.3/11.3 cm3 g–1 at 293 K for 476-MOF/477-MOF. However, their maximum CO2 uptakes are obviously different, that is, 47.6/63.2 cm3 g–1 at 273 K and 37.6/43.1 cm3 g–1 at 293 K for 476-MOF/477-MOF. The isosteric heats (Q st) of CO2, calculated based on the sorption data at 273 and 293 K, are 20.2 and 22.0 kJ mol–1 for 476-MOF and 477-MOF, respectively (see ). The larger Q st value for 477-MOF indicates a stronger interaction between CO2 and the host framework compared with that for 476-MOF, which will also account for its higher CO2 uptake at 273 and 293 K. From the structural viewpoint, the only difference for both MOFs is the central aromatic section of the ligand, which thus, can be definitely considered as the active site for CO2 adsorption.
elements.clean_text: The gas sorption isotherms for 476-MOF and 477-MOF at 273 and 293 K ( and ) indicate their extremely poor capture capacities for N2, O2, and H2 (<3.7 cm3 g-1 at both temperatures) in contrast with those for CO2 and CH4 gases. Both MOFs have comparable CH4 uptakes, 12.2/14.7 cm3 g-1 at 273 K and 10.3/11.3 cm3 g-1 at 293 K for 476-MOF/477-MOF. However, their maximum CO2 uptakes are obviously different, that is, 47.6/63.2 cm3 g-1 at 273 K and 37.6/43.1 cm3 g-1 at 293 K for 476-MOF/477-MOF. The isosteric heats (Q st) of CO2, calculated based on the sorption data at 273 and 293 K, are 20.2 and 22.0 kJ mol-1 for 476-MOF and 477-MOF, respectively (see ). The larger Q st value for 477-MOF indicates a stronger interaction between CO2 and the host framework compared with that for 476-MOF, which will also account for its higher CO2 uptake at 273 and 293 K. From the structural viewpoint, the only difference for both MOFs is the central aromatic section of the ligand, which thus, can be definitely considered as the active site for CO2 adsorption.

elements.content: The sorption selectivity was evaluated by the ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) calculations and sorption simulations at 273 and 293 K for both MOFs. The results reveal that the CO2/CH4 adsorption selectivity for 477-MOF is significantly higher than that for 476-MOF at both 273 and 293 K. The enhanced CO2 sorption selectivity over N2 and O2 at 273 K is also observed for 477-MOF (), whereas those selectivities at 293 K are almost comparable for both MOFs (). Considering their isostructural nature, the result can be properly attributed to the different interactions of CO2–phenyl and CO2–triazinyl in both MOFs. Theoretically, the improved CO2 uptake and selectivity as well as the higher Q st for 477-MOF can be appropriately explained with the viewpoint that the rich nitrogen atoms incorporated in triazinyl can serve as the Lewis-base centers to enhance the dipole–quadrupole interactions with the CO2 gas. The broad-spectrum and high adsorption selectivity of CO2 makes 477-MOF a potential porous material for CO2 separation.
elements.clean_text: The sorption selectivity was evaluated by the ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) calculations and sorption simulations at 273 and 293 K for both MOFs. The results reveal that the CO2/CH4 adsorption selectivity for 477-MOF is significantly higher than that for 476-MOF at both 273 and 293 K. The enhanced CO2 sorption selectivity over N2 and O2  at 273 K is also observed for 477-MOF (), whereas those selectivities at 293 K are almost comparable for both MOFs (). Considering their isostructural nature, the result can be properly attributed to the different interactions of CO2-phenyl and CO2-triazinyl in both MOFs. Theoretically, the improved CO2 uptake and selectivity as well as the higher Q st for 477-MOF can be appropriately explained with the viewpoint that the rich nitrogen atoms incorporated in triazinyl can serve as the Lewis-base centers to enhance the dipole-quadrupole interactions with the CO2 gas. The broad-spectrum and high adsorption selectivity of CO2 makes 477-MOF a potential porous material for CO2 separation.

elements.content: Sorption selectivity of CO2 over other gases (15:85) for 476-MOF and 477-MOF calculated using IAST model at 273 K.
elements.clean_text: 3  Sorption selectivity of CO2 over other gases (15:85) for 476-MOF and 477-MOF calculated using IAST model at 273 K.

elements.content: Solid state photoluminescence spectra () with a λex of 336 nm for 476-MOF and 341 nm for 477-MOF show the characteristic emissions of DyIII ions at ca. 480 nm (4 F 9/2 → 6 H 15/2), 573 nm (4 F 9/2 → 6 H 13/2), and 663 nm (4 F 9/2 → 6 H 11/2). In addition, the broad emission band at 374 nm for 476-MOF should be ascribed to the intraligand π → π* transitions.
elements.clean_text: Solid state photoluminescence spectra () with a λex of 336 nm for 476-MOF and 341 nm for 477-MOF show the characteristic emissions of DyIII ions at ca. 480 nm (4 F 9/2 → 6 H 15/2), 573 nm (4 F 9/2 → 6 H 13/2), and 663 nm (4 F 9/2 → 6 H 11/2). In addition, the broad emission band at 374 nm for 476-MOF should be ascribed to the intraligand π → π* transitions.

elements.content: In summary, two isostructural LnIII MOFs, which feature similar available voids but different central phenyl or triazinyl spacers of the tribenzoate ligands, were first designed and prepared. A comparison study of gas adsorption for both MOFs illustrates a clear insight into the advantage of exposed nitrogen atoms in improving both the adsorption amount and selectivity for CO2 capture. These results will provide new perspectives for the design of MOFs materials with modified capability in gas storage and/or separation.
elements.clean_text: In summary, two isostructural LnIII MOFs, which feature similar available voids but different central phenyl or triazinyl spacers of the tribenzoate ligands, were first designed and prepared. A comparison study of gas adsorption for both MOFs illustrates a clear insight into the advantage of exposed nitrogen atoms in improving both the adsorption amount and selectivity for CO2 capture. These results will provide new perspectives for the design of MOFs materials with modified capability in gas storage and/or separation.

cln_elements.content:
The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves of 476-MOF and 477-MOF () indicate that the first weight loss from 20 to 270 °C corresponds to a loss of solvent guests. The subsequent weight loss occurs in the 330–390 °C range, which can be ascribed to the exclusion of dimethylammonium cations. Beyond that temperature, pyrolysis of the host framework is observed. To evaluate the porosity for 476-MOF and 477-MOF, gas adsorption experiments were carried out by using the activated materials at different temperatures (see for details). 476-MOF and 477-MOF display similar type I isotherms (see ) with saturated uptakes of 266 and 274 cm3 g–1 for N2 at 77 K and 1 atm. Fitting the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation to N2 adsorption isotherms gives the estimated surface areas of 898 and 902 m2 g–1 for 476-MOF and 477-MOF, respectively, which are higher than those for the reported TATB-based PCN-17 series (606–820 m2 g–1). The H2 adsorption isotherm for 476-MOF indicates a moderate uptake of 1.60 wt % (179 cm3 g–1) at 77 K and 1 atm, while 477-MOF shows a slightly higher uptake of 1.77 wt % (198 cm3 g–1) under the same conditions. Also, the maximum O2 uptake is 302 cm3 g–1 (43.1 wt %) for 476-MOF, and a higher uptake of 330 cm3 g–1 (47.1 wt %) is for 477-MOF.

The gas sorption isotherms for 476-MOF and 477-MOF at 273 and 293 K ( and ) indicate their extremely poor capture capacities for N2, O2, and H2 (<3.7 cm3 g–1 at both temperatures) in contrast with those for CO2 and CH4 gases. Both MOFs have comparable CH4 uptakes, 12.2/14.7 cm3 g–1 at 273 K and 10.3/11.3 cm3 g–1 at 293 K for 476-MOF/477-MOF. However, their maximum CO2 uptakes are obviously different, that is, 47.6/63.2 cm3 g–1 at 273 K and 37.6/43.1 cm3 g–1 at 293 K for 476-MOF/477-MOF. The isosteric heats (Q st) of CO2, calculated based on the sorption data at 273 and 293 K, are 20.2 and 22.0 kJ mol–1 for 476-MOF and 477-MOF, respectively (see ). The larger Q st value for 477-MOF indicates a stronger interaction between CO2 and the host framework compared with that for 476-MOF, which will also account for its higher CO2 uptake at 273 and 293 K. From the structural viewpoint, the only difference for both MOFs is the central aromatic section of the ligand, which thus, can be definitely considered as the active site for CO2 adsorption.

The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves of 476-MOF and 477-MOF () indicate that the first weight loss from 20 to 270 °C corresponds to a loss of solvent guests. The subsequent weight loss occurs in the 330-390 °C range, which can be ascribed to the exclusion of dimethylammonium cations. Beyond that temperature, pyrolysis of the host framework is observed. To evaluate the porosity for 476-MOF and 477-MOF, gas adsorption experiments were carried out by using the activated materials at different temperatures (see  for details). 476-MOF and 477-MOF display similar type I isotherms (see ) with saturated uptakes of 266 and 274 cm3 g-1 for N2 at 77 K and 1 atm. Fitting the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation to N2 adsorption isotherms gives the estimated surface areas of 898 and 902 m2 g-1 for 476-MOF and 477-MOF, respectively, which are higher than those for the reported TATB-based PCN-17 series (606-820 m2 g-1). The H2 adsorption isotherm for 476-MOF indicates a moderate uptake of 1.60 wt % (179 cm3 g-1) at 77 K and 1 atm, while 477-MOF shows a slightly higher uptake of 1.77 wt % (198 cm3 g-1) under the same conditions. Also, the maximum O2 uptake is 302 cm3 g-1 (43.1 wt %) for 476-MOF, and a higher uptake of 330 cm3 g-1 (47.1 wt %) is for 477-MOF.

The gas sorption isotherms for 476-MOF and 477-MOF at 273 and 293 K ( and ) indicate their extremely poor capture capacities for N2, O2, and H2 (<3.7 cm3 g-1 at both temperatures) in contrast with those for CO2 and CH4 gases. Both MOFs have comparable CH4 uptakes, 12.2/14.7 cm3 g-1 at 273 K and 10.3/11.3 cm3 g-1 at 293 K for 476-MOF/477-MOF. However, their maximum CO2 uptakes are obviously different, that is, 47.6/63.2 cm3 g-1 at 273 K and 37.6/43.1 cm3 g-1 at 293 K for 476-MOF/477-MOF. The isosteric heats (Q st) of CO2, calculated based on the sorption data at 273 and 293 K, are 20.2 and 22.0 kJ mol-1 for 476-MOF and 477-MOF, respectively (see ). The larger Q st value for 477-MOF indicates a stronger interaction between CO2 and the host framework compared with that for 476-MOF, which will also account for its higher CO2 uptake at 273 and 293 K. From the structural viewpoint, the only difference for both MOFs is the central aromatic section of the ligand, which thus, can be definitely considered as the active site for CO2 adsorption.

metadata.title:
A Clear Insight into the Distinguishing CO2 Capture by
Two Isostructural DyIII–Carboxylate
Coordination Frameworks
